Abstract of the Dissertation presented to EPQB/UFRJ as a partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science (M. Sc.)

This work consists of the comparison of variables of interest (wall shear stress and flowrates) before and after placement of a flow diverter devi ce on a saccular aneurysm located in the Mid dle Cerebral artery (MCA) bifurcation , in order to verify treatment‚Äôs efficiency and safety for a real patient -specific geometry scenario. Usage of f low diverting stents in the treatment of intracranial aneurysms is widespread due to it being a minimally i nvasive technique that does not require craniotomy. This treatment possesses a high success rate, with low recidivism and complications rates. However, its limits of applicability are still being debated, as device manufacturers still do not indicate usage for aneurysms located in bifurcations, scenario that represents the majority of cases. The biggest concern on this case is the risk of ischemia due to the reduction of blood flow to the jailed branch. Despite the increasing amo unt of works that utilize computational fluid dynamics (CFD ) to study how hemodynamic variables respond to flow diverter stent placement, few seem to use it to verify blood f low variation between branches and to aid in the choice of the best ramification f or device placement for aneurysms located in bifurcations . This investigation was performed in the present work, by compari ng results considering device placement on each branch of the bifurcation. A secondary goal of this work is t o run simulations that p rovide fast results, envisioning possible application to daily medical practice. For this reason, the device was simp lified as a homogeneous porous medium and a correlation was used for porosity estimation. To encompass different possible scenarios, extrem e porosity values were also simulated. Results suggest that stent placement on either branch is both safe and effective, significantly reducing wall shear stress and blood flow for the aneurysm, while maintain ing flow to the jailed branched within acceptab le limits. Keywords: Aneurysm, Bifurcation, Flow diverting stent, CFD, Pulsatile flow, Transient Simulation, Porosity, Wall Shear Stress, Ischemia .
